title: Who cleared the Western Front battlefields after WW1? - Quora

response.answer_text: In part they were cleared by United States troops. My father was a company commander in the 29th Division, Ordinance Corp. US Army assigned to France in 1918. After the war, his company was assigned the task of clearing a section of the front not far from Orleans. He told me many stories of how the battlefield area was so churned by artillery that the landscape looked like a storm at sea that had been frozen. Not a tree survived. He said you couldn’t pick up a handful of dirt without finding pieces of metal and sometimes human body parts as well. He picked up a boot and bones fell out; another time he picked up a helmet and a skull fell out. The Americans went home as soon as they could — his company was repatriated in July, 1919 — unlike post-war Europe in the late ‘40s, so American involvement in the cleanup was limited, but it was real, and it was emotionally scaring for the participants.

When the war ended many troops were kept in France and Belgium the main reason was body recovery and burial - an task that was carried out for about 4 years (at tremendous mental damage to the men doing it - from the few accounts there are they were well supplied with alcohol and used it to keep going) Massive quantities of unexploded ordinance was blown up, though gas shells were dumped at sea - the unexploded ordinance was so common that in 1920 the growing number of sightseers becoming casualties forced the French Government to cordon off the main battlefields The process of cleaning up is still not complete the Farmers in France and Belgium call it the “Iron Harvest” and it is a common sight to see WW1 shells stacked by the road side awaiting collection by the Belgian Army In the Ypres salient it is estimated that 300 Million projectiles were fired and that 1 in 3 failed to explode in 2014 just in the Ypres area 160 tons of live ordinance was recovered and made safe
